title: Chinese Embassy donated K10,000 to Sacred Heart International Primary School in PNG for a multi-purpose building
description: On December 9, 2004, the Chinese Ambassador Li Zhengjun donated K10,000 on behalf of the Chinese Embassy to the Sacred Heart International Primary School in Papua New Guinea. The donation was used by the school to build a multi-purpose building.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Embassy donated K10,000 to Sacred Heart International Primary School in PNG for a multi-purpose building

# Description
On December 9, 2004, the Chinese Ambassador Li Zhengjun donated K10,000 on behalf of the Chinese Embassy to the Sacred Heart International Primary School in Papua New Guinea. The donation was used by the school to build a multi-purpose building.
justification: Project is a donation for educational infrastructure with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation for multi-purpose building at primary school, education sector focus

title: Chinese Government provides $2.8 million grant — via ETCA — for Government House Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#42108)
description: On May 19, 2004, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed an exchange of letters, which committed approximately $2.8 million (PGK 9 million) of grant funding for the Government House Renovation Project. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed by the two governments in December 2003 and at least one additional ETCA. The purpose of the project was to renovate the Government House — including residences for public officials and a reception lobby — in the capital city of Port Moresby.    Guangdong Foreign Construction Company (GDFC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in January 2007 and ended on May 31, 2007. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on February 20, 2008.
staff_comments: This project is also known as the PNG Governor’s Mansion Renovation Project and the Governor Hall Renovation Project. The Chinese project title is 建的总督府修缮与扩建项目 or 援巴布亚新几内亚总督府修缮.The December 2003 ETCA, which committed PGK 10.3 million of grant funding for multiple projects, is captured in Project ID#42108.
combined_text:
# Sector
GOVERNMENT AND CIVIL SOCIETY

# Title
Chinese Government provides $2.8 million grant — via ETCA — for Government House Renovation Project (Linked to Project ID#42108)

# Description
On May 19, 2004, China’s Ministry of Commerce (MOFCOM) and the Government of Papua New Guinea signed an exchange of letters, which committed approximately $2.8 million (PGK 9 million) of grant funding for the Government House Renovation Project. The grant proceeds were drawn from an Economic and Technical Cooperation Agreement (ETCA) signed by the two governments in December 2003 and at least one additional ETCA. The purpose of the project was to renovate the Government House — including residences for public officials and a reception lobby — in the capital city of Port Moresby.    Guangdong Foreign Construction Company (GDFC) was the contractor responsible for implementation. Construction began in January 2007 and ended on May 31, 2007. The project was officially completed and handed over to the local authorities on February 20, 2008.
justification: Project involves renovation of government buildings without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Government House renovation, residences for public officials, reception lobby

title: Chinese Government donated 6 vehicles to Papua New Guinea government
description: In 2004, the Chinese Government donated 1 executive vehicle, 2 ambulances, and 3 police vehicles to the Department of National Planning and Rural Development of Papua New Guinea.  The value of the donation is unknown.

title: Chinese Ministry of Culture donates 200 books to the National Library of Peru
description: On June 22, 2004, the Chinese Vice-Minister of Culture, donated 200 books about culture to the National Library of Peru (Spanish: Biblioteca Nacional del Perú). The donation occurred at the end of the Meeting for Bilateral Consultations about Education and Culture between the Chinese and Peruvian governments in Lima (see "ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN..."). The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
staff_comments: If link to 'ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN...' does not work, download a copy of document at Derecho Internacional source (CTRL+F for 3086-A).
combined_text:
# Sector
OTHER SOCIAL INFRASTRUCTURE AND SERVICES

# Title
Chinese Ministry of Culture donates 200 books to the National Library of Peru

# Description
On June 22, 2004, the Chinese Vice-Minister of Culture, donated 200 books about culture to the National Library of Peru (Spanish: Biblioteca Nacional del Perú). The donation occurred at the end of the Meeting for Bilateral Consultations about Education and Culture between the Chinese and Peruvian governments in Lima (see "ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN..."). The monetary value of this donation is unknown.
justification: Project is a cultural donation with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Donation of 200 books about culture to National Library of Peru, cultural exchange focus

title: Chinese Government provides 30 scholarships for Peruvian advanced, graduate, and post-graduate students (2004-2006)
description: On June 22, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Peru signed an agreement committing to a Cultural Exchange Program for the period of 2004-2006. Part of this program included the provision, by the Chinese Government, of ten comprehensive scholarships to Peru per year during this period (for a total of 30 scholarships). The scholarships would be for advanced, graduate, and post-graduate studies at Chinese universities. Additionally, the Peruvian Government committed to providing an undefined number of scholarships per year to Chinese students under this agreement (see "ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN..."; Article XXII specifically covers these commitments). The monetary value of these scholarships are unknown.
staff_comments: If direct link to 'ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN' does not work, find/download a copy at Derecho Internacional source by CTRL+F for 3086-A.
combined_text:
# Sector
EDUCATION

# Title
Chinese Government provides 30 scholarships for Peruvian advanced, graduate, and post-graduate students (2004-2006)

# Description
On June 22, 2004, the Chinese Government and the Government of Peru signed an agreement committing to a Cultural Exchange Program for the period of 2004-2006. Part of this program included the provision, by the Chinese Government, of ten comprehensive scholarships to Peru per year during this period (for a total of 30 scholarships). The scholarships would be for advanced, graduate, and post-graduate studies at Chinese universities. Additionally, the Peruvian Government committed to providing an undefined number of scholarships per year to Chinese students under this agreement (see "ACTA FINAL REUNIÓN..."; Article XXII specifically covers these commitments). The monetary value of these scholarships are unknown.
justification: Project focuses on educational scholarships without direct environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: Scholarship program for advanced studies, cultural exchange focus

title: China's Herbal Medical University/BioMedical Engineering Center provides $28 million USD credit facility for purchase of medicines
description: On September 2, 2004, Chairman Jiang Zemin of the Central Military Commissions met with President Arroyo of the Philippines in Zhongnanhai. The two countries signed an agreement to provide a $28 million USD credit facility from Herbal Medical University/BioMedical Engineering Center for the Philippine International Trading Corp for the purchase of medicines. The present status of this project is unknown.
staff_comments: The funding agency is coded as Unspecified Chinese Government Institution because there is no detailed information of the Herbal Medical University/BioMedical Engineering Center mentioned in the source.
combined_text:
# Sector
HEALTH

# Title
China's Herbal Medical University/BioMedical Engineering Center provides $28 million USD credit facility for purchase of medicines

# Description
On September 2, 2004, Chairman Jiang Zemin of the Central Military Commissions met with President Arroyo of the Philippines in Zhongnanhai. The two countries signed an agreement to provide a $28 million USD credit facility from Herbal Medical University/BioMedical Engineering Center for the Philippine International Trading Corp for the purchase of medicines. The present status of this project is unknown.
justification: Project involves healthcare-related funding for medicine purchases, with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Credit facility for purchase of medicines, healthcare sector focus

title: China donates $50,000 for flood relief in the Philippines after typhoons Violeta and Unding
description: On November 26 2004, the Chinese Government donated $50,000 USD to the Philippines after Typhoon Violeta and Typhoon Unding triggered floods in the northern parts of the country.
combined_text:
# Sector
EMERGENCY RESPONSE

# Title
China donates $50,000 for flood relief in the Philippines after typhoons Violeta and Unding

# Description
On November 26 2004, the Chinese Government donated $50,000 USD to the Philippines after Typhoon Violeta and Typhoon Unding triggered floods in the northern parts of the country.
justification: Humanitarian aid for disaster relief with no direct environmental or energy transition impact
evidence: Flood relief donation, no infrastructure or energy components

title: Overseas Chinese Affairs Office sends traditional Chinese physicians to the Philippines
description: From June 4 to June 24, 2004, a team of traditional Chinese medical experts provided free medical consultations in Manila, Caloocan, Baguio, Iloilo, and Cebu. This project was financed by the Overseas Chinese Affairs Office.

title: China Eximbank disburses $180.79 million via preferential buyer's credit for Phase I, Section I of Northrail Project (Linked with Project ID#63583 and #63576)
description: On August 30, 2003, China Eximbank and the Department of Finance of the Philippines (DOF) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), wherein China Eximbank agreed to extend a preferential buyer’s credit to the Philippine Government to finance the Northrail Project for an amount not to exceed $400,000,000. Then, on February 26, 2004, DOF and China Eximbank signed a $400 million preferential buyer’s credit loan agreement (No. BLA 04055) for Phase I, Section I of the Northrail Project. The loan reportedly carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 8.25 year grace period, and 3% interest rate. DOF, in turn, on-lent the proceeds of the loan to North Luzon Railways Corporation (NLRC or Northrail). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the ultimate borrower (Northrail) to partially finance a $421,050,000 commercial (turnkey) contract between Northrail and China National Machinery and Equipment Group (CNMEG), which was signed on December 30, 2003.   The purpose of the project was to build an 80 km railway line from Caloocan in Metro Manila to the city of Malolos (within the province of Bulacan) to promote economic development north of Metro Manila. The railway line would have passed through Valenzuela, Marilao, Bocaue, and Guguinto.  A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 5, 2004. However, Northrail did not issue a ‘notice to proceed’ to CNMEG until February 26, 2007.   On May 15, 2007, the Supreme Court of the Philippines ruled that the loan agreement was a commercial deal and not a government-to-government one and as such it should have undergone competitive bidding.  On July 6, 2012, China Eximbank advised DOF that it was cancelling the undisbursed balance of the $400 million loan and it demanded immediate payment of $180.79 million drawn from the $400 million loan. DOF was able to negotiate with China Eximbank to pay $180.79 million of loan principal plus interest in four equal installments over two years (starting on September 21, 2012). As of January 21, 2014, DOF had repaid China Eximbank the full amount of $180.79 million plus interest.  Project ID#63805 captures the $180.79 million loan disbursement and Project ID#63576 captures the loan cancelation. Project ID#63583 captures a separate $500 million (cancelled) loan commitment for Phase I, Section II of the Northrail Project.
staff_comments: 1. The China Eximbank loan that supported this project is not included in the the Overseas Development Finance Dataset that Boston University’s Global Development Policy Center published in December 2020.2. The Government of Philippines loan identification number for the China Eximbank loan that supported Phase I, Section I of Northrail Project is BLA-04055.3. The original commercial contract from December 30, 2003 was amended on September 29, 2009, increasing the contract cost from $421.05 million to $593.88 million. On August 22, 2012, CNMEG terminated the project after questions on the validity of the contract were raised and filed in court. CNMEG subsequently submitted claims for payment for work already done. On November 6, 2017, the Government of the Philippines and CNMEG reached an out-of-court settlement agreement over their contractual dispute. Under the agreement, both parties agreed to waive their claims against each other and declared that there would be no more payments between Northrail and CNMEG/Sinomach. The parties also agreed to share the remaining arbitration fees equally.  4. CNMEG was eventually renamed China National Machinery Industry Corporation (Sinomach).
combined_text:
# Sector
TRANSPORT AND STORAGE

# Title
China Eximbank disburses $180.79 million via preferential buyer's credit for Phase I, Section I of Northrail Project (Linked with Project ID#63583 and #63576)

# Description
On August 30, 2003, China Eximbank and the Department of Finance of the Philippines (DOF) signed a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU), wherein China Eximbank agreed to extend a preferential buyer’s credit to the Philippine Government to finance the Northrail Project for an amount not to exceed $400,000,000. Then, on February 26, 2004, DOF and China Eximbank signed a $400 million preferential buyer’s credit loan agreement (No. BLA 04055) for Phase I, Section I of the Northrail Project. The loan reportedly carried the following terms: 20 year maturity, 8.25 year grace period, and 3% interest rate. DOF, in turn, on-lent the proceeds of the loan to North Luzon Railways Corporation (NLRC or Northrail). The proceeds of the loan were to be used by the ultimate borrower (Northrail) to partially finance a $421,050,000 commercial (turnkey) contract between Northrail and China National Machinery and Equipment Group (CNMEG), which was signed on December 30, 2003.   The purpose of the project was to build an 80 km railway line from Caloocan in Metro Manila to the city of Malolos (within the province of Bulacan) to promote economic development north of Metro Manila. The railway line would have passed through Valenzuela, Marilao, Bocaue, and Guguinto.  A formal groundbreaking ceremony took place on April 5, 2004. However, Northrail did not issue a ‘notice to proceed’ to CNMEG until February 26, 2007.   On May 15, 2007, the Supreme Court of the Philippines ruled that the loan agreement was a commercial deal and not a government-to-government one and as such it should have undergone competitive bidding.  On July 6, 2012, China Eximbank advised DOF that it was cancelling the undisbursed balance of the $400 million loan and it demanded immediate payment of $180.79 million drawn from the $400 million loan. DOF was able to negotiate with China Eximbank to pay $180.79 million of loan principal plus interest in four equal installments over two years (starting on September 21, 2012). As of January 21, 2014, DOF had repaid China Eximbank the full amount of $180.79 million plus interest.  Project ID#63805 captures the $180.79 million loan disbursement and Project ID#63576 captures the loan cancelation. Project ID#63583 captures a separate $500 million (cancelled) loan commitment for Phase I, Section II of the Northrail Project.
justification: Railway construction project primarily focused on transportation infrastructure development without clear environmental or energy transition impacts
evidence: 80 km railway line construction, economic development focus, no mention of renewable energy or energy transition components
